G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is an action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 20.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 3 and 20, the Boston Housing Court has jurisdiction over this action because it concerns residential rental property in Boston and alleges violations of state landlord‑tenant law related to the condition and use of the leased premises.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the premises are located in Boston and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in Boston. See G.L. c. 223, § 1; G.L. c. 185C, § 3.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: As landlord of the Premises, Defendant owed Plaintiff all duties imposed by Massachusetts common law, the implied warranty of habitability, G.L. c. 186, and applicable state and local sanitary and building codes, including but not limited to the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. See Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: Hemingway does recognize, as a matter of Massachusetts common law, that a residential landlord has obligations tied to compliance with statutory and regulatory housing standards, and it is the seminal case on the implied warranty of habitability. However, the quoted concurring/dissenting passage is not the majority’s holding and does not state that ‘as landlord of the Premises, Defendant owed Plaintiff all duties imposed by Massachusetts common law, the implied warranty of habitability, G.L. c. 186, and applicable state and local codes.’ The case focuses on implying obligations measured by the State Sanitary Code and related statutes, not on the broad, cumulative formulation in the proposition, and the portion provided is not a clear holding imposing all those duties as framed.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: As landlord of the Premises, Defendant owed Plaintiff all duties imposed by Massachusetts common law, the implied warranty of habitability, G.L. c. 186, and applicable state and local sanitary and building codes, including but not limited to the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. See Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).

105 CMR 410.200.proposition: Continuous dampness and water seepage in a basement apartment render the dwelling unit unhealthy and unfit for human habitation and violate the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, including but not limited to 105 CMR 410.200 (prohibiting chronic dampness and water penetration), 105 CMR 410.500 et seq. (structural requirements), and related provisions requiring the landlord to maintain the premises in a safe, sanitary, and weather‑tight condition.

105 CMR 410.500 et seq..proposition: Continuous dampness and water seepage in a basement apartment render the dwelling unit unhealthy and unfit for human habitation and violate the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, including but not limited to 105 CMR 410.200 (prohibiting chronic dampness and water penetration), 105 CMR 410.500 et seq. (structural requirements), and related provisions requiring the landlord to maintain the premises in a safe, sanitary, and weather‑tight condition.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts and protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious and substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the premises. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes “quiet enjoyment” as a familiar landlord‑tenant term signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy, and states that every tenancy is deemed to include an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb that right. It also ties this concept directly to residential premises under G.L. c. 186, § 14. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts residential tenancies carry an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting against serious and substantial interference with use and enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ — words that have little inherent meaning but a rich background in decisional law — it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts and protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious and substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the premises. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997).
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and its fault requirement, and notes that the statute codified tenants’ common-law rights, but it does not clearly state that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy, nor does it explicitly define the covenant in terms of “freedom from serious and substantial interference.” Those broader propositions come from Simon v. Solomon and related cases. Al‑Ziab focuses on the level of landlord fault (at least negligence) required to establish a § 14 violation, not on the universal implication or the specific “serious and substantial interference” formulation.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises… Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: Constructive interference with quiet enjoyment may arise from conditions within the landlord’s control that “substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises” and that the landlord fails to remedy within a reasonable time after notice, including violations of the State Sanitary Code. See, e.g., Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977); Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–02 (1979); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–04.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: Blackett does support that constructive interference with quiet enjoyment may arise from conditions within the landlord’s control that substantially impair the value of the premises and that the landlord fails to remedy after notice. However, it does not discuss or rely on violations of the State Sanitary Code as a basis for constructive interference; the case is about noise from a lounge operated by another tenant under the landlord’s control. Thus, as phrased (specifically referencing State Sanitary Code violations and grouping Blackett with later warranty/Code cases), the proposition overstates what Blackett itself holds.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done…. Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–02 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Constructive interference with quiet enjoyment may arise from conditions within the landlord’s control that “substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises” and that the landlord fails to remedy within a reasonable time after notice, including violations of the State Sanitary Code. See, e.g., Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977); Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–02 (1979); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–04.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The Berman opinion deals with breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not constructive interference with quiet enjoyment. While it clearly holds that substantial State Sanitary Code violations (such as loss of heat and hot water) that render a dwelling uninhabitable and exist after the landlord has notice support rent abatement, it does not frame this as a quiet-enjoyment or constructive eviction doctrine. Thus, citing Berman specifically for the quiet-enjoyment proposition is inaccurate, even though the substantive habitability standard overlaps conceptually.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.” (379 Mass. at 201–03).

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 774–78 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that serious housing code violations and uncorrected moisture, leaks, and unsanitary conditions can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 774–78 (1994); Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976, 977–78 (1985); Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 198–200.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that the trial judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment but expressly declines to award or analyze damages on that claim, and the Supreme Judicial Court does not discuss what factual conditions constitute such a breach. The detailed analysis in Cruz is about the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a subsidized tenancy, not about whether serious housing code violations, moisture, leaks, or unsanitary conditions amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Thus, it does not provide substantive authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976, 977–78 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that serious housing code violations and uncorrected moisture, leaks, and unsanitary conditions can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 774–78 (1994); Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976, 977–78 (1985); Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 198–200.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.support_reasoning: The excerpt shows that the landlord was found liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and that there were continuing leaks, cockroaches, a flood, and other State Sanitary Code violations, but the Appeals Court’s discussion focuses on damages under c. 93A and rent abatement, not on defining or analyzing what constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under § 14. The opinion does not clearly articulate that serious housing code violations and uncorrected moisture/leaks/unsanitary conditions, as such, constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment; it largely assumes the § 14 violation without expounding the legal standard. Thus, it is a weak authority for the specific doctrinal proposition stated, even though the facts are consistent with it.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.relevant_excerpt: “Damages were awarded under G. L. c. 93A, the judge concluding that his findings of negligence and of breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and of G. L. c. 186, § 14, ‘also constitute a violation of G. L. c. 93A.’… The judge’s award based on a wilful or knowing violation is supported by evidence that the previous tenant… was unsuccessful in obtaining repairs and that some of the problems (leaks) had persisted for three and a half years and continued to the time of the trial in 1983. While each violation may not in itself have been wilful… there were many continuing violations, some major and some minor, their cumulative effect on habitability can be considered…”}

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., landlords are obligated to maintain residential premises in compliance with health and safety standards. Failure to maintain the premises in compliance with these standards, after notice, is evidence of interference with quiet enjoyment and breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt., 417 Mass. at 775–77; McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429 Mass. 300, 305–06 (1999).

McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.raw_text: McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429 Mass. 300, 305–06 (1999)
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., landlords are obligated to maintain residential premises in compliance with health and safety standards. Failure to maintain the premises in compliance with these standards, after notice, is evidence of interference with quiet enjoyment and breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt., 417 Mass. at 775–77; McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429 Mass. 300, 305–06 (1999).
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.support_reasoning: McAllister involves State Sanitary and Building Code provisions that require the landlord to keep exterior stairs free of snow and ice, and the SJC holds that a violation of those codes is evidence of negligence. However, the opinion does not state that failure to maintain premises in compliance with those codes, after notice, constitutes evidence of interference with quiet enjoyment or a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14. In fact, the court treats quiet enjoyment and lease claims as negligence-based and ultimately upholds directed verdicts against the tenant, and it further holds that this type of code violation does not amount to a breach of the implied warranty of habitability. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.relevant_excerpt: “We reject the plaintiff’s contention that she is entitled to a new trial based on her claims that the defendant violated the lease and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, G. L. c. 186, § 14. Negligence is a prerequisite for recovery under both theories… Both the lease and the State code provisions merely restated a duty which the defendant acknowledged.… Although the code provisions established a duty on the part of the defendant to remove snow and ice, the defendant never challenged that it owed the plaintiff that duty.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord’s interference with quiet enjoyment need not be accompanied by actual physical eviction; indirect actions, omissions, or conditions that substantially impair the tenant’s comfort, safety, or use of the premises are sufficient. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718–19; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 to cover serious interferences with tenancy caused by what the landlord “failed to do, or permitted to be done,” and applies that standard to conditions (drug activity and resulting fear and loss of use of common areas) that do not involve any physical eviction. The Court holds that if the landlord’s omissions in addressing third-party criminal activity create a condition that substantially interferes with tenants’ use of the premises, that may constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment under § 14. This directly supports the proposition that indirect actions or omissions that substantially impair tenants’ comfort, safety, or use are sufficient to violate § 14 without actual eviction.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: In addition, Massachusetts law protects tenants who report code violations or contact public authorities regarding housing conditions from retaliatory conduct by landlords, and such retaliation may constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See G.L. c. 186, § 18; Sanitary Code enforcement provisions, G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; see also Spence v. Gormley, 387 Mass. 258, 262–64 (1982) (discussing landlord retaliation based on tenant’s protected activity).

Spence v. Gormley, 387 Mass. 258, 262\u2.proposition: In addition, Massachusetts law protects tenants who report code violations or contact public authorities regarding housing conditions from retaliatory conduct by landlords, and such retaliation may constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See G.L. c. 186, § 18; Sanitary Code enforcement provisions, G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; see also Spence v. Gormley, 387 Mass. 258, 262–64 (1982) (discussing landlord retaliation based on tenant’s protected activity).
Spence v. Gormley, 387 Mass. 258, 262\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Spence v. Gormley concerns whether a public housing authority may evict tenants based on violent acts of household members and how G.L. c. 121B, § 32’s ‘cause’ requirement and due process apply. It does not discuss retaliation for reporting code violations, G.L. c. 186, § 18, the Sanitary Code enforcement scheme, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Using this case as authority for Massachusetts protections against landlord retaliation based on tenants’ reports to public authorities misstates its subject and holding.
Spence v. Gormley, 387 Mass. 258, 262\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the lease forms signed by both tenants, and the termination provisions of G. L. c. 121B, § 32, authorize the BHA to terminate housing project tenancies on the basis of serious acts of violence, committed at the projects by members of the tenants’ household. … With this limitation, at least, termination based on a preponderance of evidence that a member of the tenant’s household committed serious acts of violence on BHA premises is consistent with due process.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
